case_name: Sardul Singh Caveeshar & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 to 56 of 1957 were filed in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 to 56 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arose from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated November 21, 1956 in Criminal Appeals Nos. 861-864 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 861-864 of 1956 arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Bombay High Court appeals arose from Additional Sessions Judge for Greater Bombay judgment dated June 1, 1956 in Sessions Case No. 27/111 Sessions 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and order dated June 1, 1956, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge for Greater Bombay at Bombay in Sessions Case No. 27/111 Sessions 1955.

facts.text: Four appellants along with Ramniklal Keshavlal Jhaveri (acquitted) were committed for trial on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust of Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd. funds.

anchor.surface_text: These are appeals by special leave by four persons, who along with one Ramniklal Keshavlal Jhaveri since acquitted were committed for trial in the Court of the Sessions Judge of Greater Bombay, on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust of the funds of the Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Conspiracy period was from December 1, 1948 to January 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The charge of conspiracy related to the period from December 1, 1948, to January 31, 1949,

facts.text: Appellants Sardul Singh Caveeshar and Parmeshwar Nath Kaul found guilty by majority verdict of jury.

anchor.surface_text: All of them except Jhaveri were found guilty, appellants in Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54, Sardul Singh Caveeshar and Parmeshwar Nath Kaul, by a majority verdict

facts.text: Appellants Vallabhdas Pulchand Mehta and Charucharan Guha found guilty by unanimous verdict of jury.

anchor.surface_text: and appellants in Criminal Appeals Nos. 55 and 56, Vallabhdas Pulchand Mehta and Charucharan Guha, by an unanimous verdict.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Sardul Singh Caveeshar to rigorous imprisonment for three years and fine of Rs. 2,500.

anchor.surface_text: The verdicts- of the jury were accepted by the Sessions Judge who sentenced the appellants as follows Appellant Sardul Singh Caveeshar to rigorous imprisonment for three years and a fine of Rs. 2,500.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Parmeshwar Nath Kaul to rigorous imprisonment for five years and fine of Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Parmeshwar Nath Kaul to rigorous imprisonment for five years and a fine of Rs. 5,000.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Vallabhdas Phulchand Mehta to rigorous imprisonment for five years and fine of Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Vallabhdas Phulchand Mehta to rigorous imprisonment for five years and a fine of Rs. 5,000.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Charucharan Guha to rigorous imprisonment for three years and fine of Rs. 2,500.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Charucharan Guha to rigorous imprisonment for three years and a fine of Rs. 2,500.

facts.text: Lala Shankarlal Hiralal Bansal and Saubhagyachand Umedchand Doshi died before commencement of the trial.

anchor.surface_text: of whom two Lala Shankarlal Hiralal Bansal hereinafter referred to as Lala Shankarlal and Saubhagyachand Umedchand Doshi hereinafter referred to as Doshi died before commencement of the trial.

facts.text: Trial against Lala Ram Sharandas alias Ramsharan Lala Haricharan Mahajan was separated.

anchor.surface_text: One Lala Ram Sharandas alias Ramsharan Lala Haricharan Mahajan hereinafter referred to as Mahajan was also a party to the conspiracy. But for some reason or other, the trial against him was separated.

facts.text: Lala Shankarlal was managing director of Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd., New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Lala Shankarlal, who was residing at No. 16, Bara Khamba Road, New Delhi, was the managing director of the Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd., New Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Tropical.

facts.text: Parmeshwar Nath Kaul (accused No. 1) was a barrister in Delhi in December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Accused No. 1, Kaul, is a barrister and was in Lahore till the partition of the country. In December, 1948, he was in Delhi.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Phulchand Mehta (accused No. 2) was manager of Bombay Office (General) of Tropical at material times.

anchor.surface_text: Accused No. 2 Mehta, at all material times was the manager of the Bombay Office General of the Tropical.

facts.text: Prosecution case: Lala Shankarlal planned to acquire controlling block of Jupiter shares using Jupiter's own funds.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution is that Lala Shankarlal who was the brain behind the conspiracy and who at the time was the managing director and had the control of the Tropical, which by then was financially in a tottering condition, planned along with his confederates to obtain the control of the Jupiter, which at the time was in a sound financial position, by acquiring the controlling block of shares of the Jupiter and utilising the funds of the Jupiter itself for the acquisition of such shares.

facts.text: Jupiter had investments of face value Rs. two crores and 1,24,966 ordinary shares of Rs. 100 each (Rs. 15 called up).

anchor.surface_text: By the date of the conspiracy the Jupiter had investments of the face value of Rs. two crores. It had issued 1,24,966 ordinary shares of Rs. 100 -each of which Rs. 15 per share was called up.

facts.text: Bargain settled for purchase of controlling block of about 63,000 Jupiter shares at Rs. 53 per share for Rs. 33,39,000.

anchor.surface_text: After negotiations, conducted first through certain persons called Mayadas and Chopra and then, through one Naurangrai, a bargain was settled with Khaitan for the purchase of this controlling block of shares at Rs. 53 per share for a sum of Rs. 33,39,000.

facts.text: Rs. 4,85,000 paid to Bajaj on or about December 29, 1948; formal agreement dated December 29, 1948 executed.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this agreement Rs. 4,85,000 were paid over to Bajaj on or about December 29, 1948, and a formal agreement dated December 29, 1948, was entered into, incorporating the above terms.

facts.text: On December 29, 1948, 1,250 qualifying shares allotted to Lala Shankarlal, Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri, Doshi; they appointed directors.

anchor.surface_text: On that very day Bajaj and other directors of Khaitan group held a meeting and allotted 1,250 shares straightaway to Lala Shankarlal and four of his nominees viz., Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri and Doshi, each 250 shares, as qualifying shares for each.

facts.text: Lala Shankarlal appointed managing director of Jupiter on December 29, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Khaitan resigned his position as managing director of the Jupiter and at the same meeting, Lala Shankarlal was appointed in his place as the managing director of the Jupiter.

facts.text: On January 11, 1949, Jupiter directors resolved to sell securities worth Rs. 15 lakhs and obtain overdraft of Rs. 14 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: At the meeting of some of the new directors of the Jupiter dated January 11, 1949, it was decided to sell the Jupiters securities of the face value -of Rs. 15 lakhs at the market rate and to obtain an overdraft accommodation for Rs. 14 lakhs

facts.text: Jupiter granted loan of Rs. 25,15,000 to Caveeshar on equitable mortgage on application dated January 4, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: At the same meeting a loan of Rs. 25,15,000 purported to have been granted to Caveeshar by way of an equitable mortgage on an alleged application by him dated January 4, 1949,

facts.text: Rs. 28,15,000 paid to Khaitan on January 20, 1949 using Jupiter funds via sale and pledge of its securities.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus that Khaitan received the balance of the money due under the agreement of December 29, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Mirza Akbar v. The King-Emperor  1 . In that case their Lordships of the Privy Council held that s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be construed in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the conspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the conspiracy. They notice that evidence receivable under s. 10 of the Evidence Act of anything said, done, or written, by any one of such persons (i.e. conspirators) must be in reference to their common intention.

precedents.cited_proposition: Limits of admissibility of evidence in conspiracy cases under s. 10 of the Evidence Act: evidence receivable only if in reference to common intention and done in carrying out the conspiracy; acts outside the period of conspiracy not receivable.
precedents.cited_holding: s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be construed in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the conspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the conspiracy.

anchor.surface_text: Reg. v. Prabhudas  1  when considering the scope of s. 11 of the Evidence Act. Now, there can be no doubt that one of the main relevant issues in the case is whether the loan of Rs. 25 lakhs and odd advanced on January 20, 1949, to Caveeshar, as also the moneys said to have been paid to the Delhi Stores by way of advance for purchase of certain plots said to belong to it, were genuine transactions or bogus and make-believe.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sections of the Evidence Act like s.11 are widely worded and must receive a somewhat limited construction.

precedents.citation: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales 1

anchor.surface_text: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales 1 . To anticipate a likely defence in such a case and to give evidence in rebuttal of such defence is in substance nothing more than the letting in of evidence by the prosecution of the requisite criminal intention beyond reasonable doubt.

precedents.case_name: Makin v. Attorney-General for New South Wales
precedents.cited_proposition: Evidence in rebuttal of a very likely and probable defence on the question of intention can be led by the prosecution as part of its case.

anchor.surface_text: Walli Muhammad v. King  1 . Therein their Lordships pointed out the difficulty in all cases where two persons are accused of a crime and where the evidence against one is inadmissible against the other. Their Lordships recognised that however carefully assessors or a jury are directed and however firmly a Judge may steel his mind against being influenced against one by the evidence admissible only against the other, nevertheless the mind may inadvertently be affected by the disclosures made by one of the accused to the detriment of the other.

precedents.cited_proposition: In joint trials, evidence admissible only against one accused may inadvertently prejudice the minds of judge/jury against the other despite directions.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the fact that accused No. 3, Jhaveri, has been acquitted by the unanimous verdict of the jury appears to indicate that the jury has shown itself capable of observing the caution given to them and making careful discrimination.

outcome.relief_summary: No prejudice found from evidence admissibility; limited interference in jury verdict; some acquittals noted
